overview.ovdesc:
Payment netting consolidates payments with the same value date and currency for any counterparty with whom we have a NETTING.AGREEMENT.
SUMMARY OF PAYMENT NETTING
Payment netting is only possible where we have an active NETTING.AGREEMENT with a counterparty. The netting agreement has a finite life and specifies which currencies may be net and which types of contracts may give rise to net payments.
When a payment is a valid candidate for netting, T24 will pass the entry to a suspense account instead of the nostro account and will not create a payment message in Delivery. A record will be written to the NETTING.ENTRY application for the contract and the status of the entry may be monitored here.
The CREATE.NETTING application may then be used to consolidate the outstanding payments together. These will be written to the NETTING application. There is one NETTING record for each net payment (i.e. a NETTING record is for a single customer, currency, and value date).
The NETTING record is initially placed on hold. The record may now be maintained to add settlement details, confirmation details and, if required, individual payments may be dropped from the net payment.
Upon authorisation a net payment (or receipt) message will be generated. The suspense account will be debited and the nostro will be credited.
PROCESSING OF FORWARD NET PAYMENTS
Payments arising from forward deals or from the maturity of contracts may also be netted. During the overnight batch T24 will check for net payments being made in the near future (as specified on NETTING.PARAMETERS). It will automatically create NETTING records ready for maintenance the following morning.
PARAMETERS FOR PAYMENT NETTING.
The NETTING.PARAMETERS application defines various high level specifications for netting including the transaction codes to be used for netting movements, the number of days ahead for the creation of forward netting payments, etc.
The ACCOUNT.CLASS application defines the payment netting suspense accounts on the record 'NETTING'.
The ACCOUNT.PARAMETER application defines whether the site requires netting.
PARAMETERS FOR PAYMENT NETTING TO GENERATE MT102 and MT203 FROM FUNDS TRANSFER APPLICATION
From Funds Transfer application instead of raising individual MT103 and MT202, messages can be grouped and MT102 & MT203 respectively can be sent using NETTING application. For this DE.PARM and DE.MESSAGE , Netting.Allowed flag should be set to "Yes". Based on the Value entered in Netting.Status in Funds.Transfer application, NETTING.ENTRY is created with system id as FT.
The CREATE.NETTING application may then be used to consolidate the outstanding payments together. These will be written to the NETTING application. There is one NETTING record for each net payment (i.e. a NETTING record is for a single customer, currency, and value date combination). Incase the MT202 details exceed 1 then MT203 is sent otherwise MT202 is sent. Incase the 202 records exceeds 10, then for every 10 records, single MT203 is sent.
When System.Id is FT then in NETTING application only Netting & Bk.To.Bk.102 and Bk.To.Bk.203 fields are allowed for input and the details required for the messages are defaulted from the corresponding Funds Transfer Contract.
Please note NETTING application is used by FT to generate MT102 and MT203. i.e., No Accounting entries at Netting Level for FT.

A number Generated automatically by the system after authorisation which identifies either a statement entry or a category entry in respect of a transaction. After validation but before authorisation, the value 'VAL' will be inserted in this field to indicate that the transaction has been validated successfully but is still waiting authorisation.

After authorisation of a Teller transaction, the system will automatically insert a number into this field and this number may refer to a statement entry or a category entry depending on the value contained in the corresponding multivalue fields. The following examples will illustrate the use of this field.
Example 1:
On the execution date of a transaction there will normally be an entry on a Customer account and the following type of number will be generated at this field:
The number automatically generated in field 39.1 is unique to the transaction in question and is built in the following way:
1. The first four digits '6737' indicate the number of days since the 1st of January 1968. In our example, it corresponds to the 11th of June 1986.
2. The next five digits '32684' indicate the number of seconds since midnight. In our example, it corresponds to an entry generated on line at 09:04:44 AM.
3. The last two digits '48' indicate the number of hundreds of seconds.

The value assigned (again automatically) to field 39.2 identifies the number in 39.1 as a statement entry number. If the User wishes to call this statement entry record on to the screen the User will invoke the STMT.ENTRY Application and the type the following at 'Awaiting ID' :-
where the suffix '0001' identifies it as the first statement entry (there will normally be more than one as the next example will illustrate).
Example 2:

A second example outlined here is similar to that in example 1, in that there is a statement entry on value date for both the our account and the customer account. The system handles this case as follows:

Once again field 39.1 contains the identification number automatically generated by the system while field 39.2 now contains two separate numbers signifying that there are infact two separate statement entries, one in respect of the our account pay and one in respect of the our account receive. If the User wishes to see either of these he must first of all invoke STMT.ENTRY followed by the desired function and then at 'Awaiting ID' type EITHER:
where the addition of the suffix '0001' identifies the statement entry in respect of the our account OR
where the addition of the suffix '0002' identifies the statement entry in respect of the customer account.
Example 3:

A third example might be that of a category entry generated at initiation of a transaction where commission or charges have been debited to the customer and credited to a profit and loss category code. In this case the following entries are generated on the transaction:
Once again the standard type number is generated and inserted at field 39.1
Now, however, field 39.2 is replaced by field 39.3 which now identifies the number in 39.1 as a category entry and not a statement entry.
To call this category entry record onto the screen the User must now type:

The institution (usually a bank) who will be the receiver of a payment instruction message if a cover payment is required.

Input to this field will cause two payment messages to be generated, a payment request and a cover payment request. The payment request will be sent to the bank input in this field. The cover payment will be sent to our nostro (in the SETTLE.ACCOUNT field) in the normal way.
EXAMPLE
We are paying French Francs to ABC Limited at their account at Credit Lyonnais in Paris. Our FRF nostro is BNP Paris and Credit Lyonnais take cover at Credit Agricole Paris.
We would send two messages:
An MT100 to Credit Lyonnais requesting them to credit the account of ABC Limited.
An MT202 to BNP Paris requesting them to make a payment from our account to the account of Credit Lyonnais at Credit Agricole.
The contents of the fields on the NETTING record would be:
SETTLE.ACCOUNT Nostro at BNP RECEIVER.BNK Credit Lyonnais REC.CORR.BNK Creidt Agricole BENEFICIARY ABC Limited

t.desc:
Specify the Time indication detail here, which will be mapped to tag 13C of MT102
Time indication has 3 components i.e. SWIFT.CODE.WORD, TIME.INDICATION and TIME.OFFSET.
Swift.Code.word and time indication has to be specified here.
TIME.OFFSET will get defaulted from field CET.TIME.DIFF in DE.PARM. If no value is given in DE.PARM, then defaulted to +0000
FOR EXAMPLE:
In DE.PARM application, field CET.TIME.DIFF is set as +1000 and in FT, for field TIME.IND is given as /CLSTIME/1220, then 13C tag of swift message will be /CLSTIME/1220+1000
Validation Rules:
Optional field
SWIFT.CODE.WORD entered should be a valid record in SWIFT.CODE.WORDS for the application and message type.
Time indication related code words-CLSTIME, SNDTIME, RNCTIME can be used.
Code words should be given between two slashes. I.e. /CLSTIME/
Time details given should be a valid HHMM format and HH should be between 00 to 23 and MM should be between 00 to 59
Duplicate SWIFT.CODE.WORDS not allowed for a same RELATED.MSG.
If entered Minimum and maximum number of characters is 13.
